Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction zones are places on Earth where one of Earth?s tectonic plates slides beneath another. They are locations of intense geologic activity that pose hazards to humans, including earthquakes and volcanoes. Understanding subduction zones is critical to developing our understanding of global geochemical cycles; the formation, evolution, and composition of the Earth?s crust; global-scale mantle dynamics; the distribution of valuable natural resources in ore deposits; and numerous geological hazards including volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, and tsunamis. Processes occurring deep within subduction zones are impossible to observe directly, but there are a wide variety of rocks that have been exhumed to the Earth?s surface from deep within subduction zones. Those who study these exhumed rocks have the unique ability to inform studies of active subduction zones by ?ground-truthing? the assumptions that go into models, experiments, and interpretive geophysics and geochemistry. ExTerra represents the community of scientists involved in studies of these exhumed rocks from the subduction system.

The goal of the workshop ExTerra 2013: Understanding Subduction through Studies of Exhumed Terranes is to organize disparate studies of subduction-related metamorphic and igneous rocks around a common set of scientific targets in order to move the discipline forward more efficiently as a community. In order to accomplish this goal, we will gather the communities of researchers investigating three categories of exhumed rocks from subduction zones: 1) high-pressure rocks of the subducted slab, 2) middle and lower arc crust, and 3) the mantle wedge. ExTerra 2013 will focus on research themes of common interest to these groups, provide a forum for communication and interaction among scientists, promote participation in the 2013 international Goldschmidt conference, and foster collaboration among participating scientists. We will lay the groundwork for the long-term structure of ExTerra, plan and organize future field trips, and develop an infrastructure for shared sample and data collection, archiving, and distribution. The proposed workshop will incorporate scientific presentations (talks and posters) on current research in exhumed terranes, an update on database and archiving progress, and will identify localities and organizers for field forums to be held over the next few years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ExTerra 2013 workshop in Florence, Italy focused on research themes of common interest to scientists studying subduction zone processes using metamorphic and igneous rocks exhumed from ancient subduction zones. The workshop provided a forum for communication and interaction among scientists and graduate students, promoted participation in the 2013 international Goldschmidt conference, and fostered collaboration among participating scientists. We laid the groundwork for the long-term structure of ExTerra, planned and organized future field institutes, and developed an infrastructure for shared sample and data collection, archiving, and distribution. The workshop incorporated scientific presentations (talks and posters) on current research in exhumed subduction terranes, an update on database and archiving progress, and identified localities and organizers for field forums to be held over the next several years. 

The community produced a new ExTerra white paper (January, 2014) outlining the big science questions regarding subduction zones and specifically directed towards the questions that can be addressed by studies of exhumed terranes. It has been distributed by email to individuals on the ExTerra email list and relevant program managers at the National Science Foundation. It is also available on the GeoPRISMS/ExTerra website where it is accessible to all: http://www.geoprisms.org/scd/exterra/2-uncategorised/281-exterrawhitepaper.html 

The ExTerra workshop also focused on transformative new approaches to field-based study. These include group-led Field Institutes, well-managed and publicly accessible sample archives, and centrally organized data management and distribution. A pilot Field Institute to the Salinian Block in 2014 provided an opportunity to test these approaches in the field and begin building a sample/data archive, and a recently funded Partnership in International Research and Education (PIRE) will allow ExTerra to implement these approaches on a large scale. These sample-sharing strategies have the potential to revolutionize the way geochemists and petrologists conduct field-based research.

The ExTerra 2013 Workshop was attended by 11 graduate students from 5 countries. The students participated in focus groups, gave one-minute presentations about their research between keynote lectures, and presented posters in an evening poster session. Students were able to interact with faculty members from 21 universities located in 6 countries during focus group breakout discussions, coffee breaks, and a working dinner. An associated ExTerra thematic session at the Goldschmidt Conference the following week provided yet another opportunity for students to present their research and interface with faculty. In addition to student participation, four of the ten Keynote Speakers at ExTerra 2013 were early-career faculty. Giving a Keynote address at this early stage in their careers provided an excellent opportunity to gain visibility for their research programs and attract potential students, post-docs, and collaborators.
